section.title: 1Example of free particle in one dimension

para.p:
Define

, where

is a nonzero constant. Fixing two times

γ
in
R
by

Math.text: S * gamma = ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ (t _ 1))@(L * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * differential-d@(t)) = (m / 2) * ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ (t _ 1))@((dot@(gamma) * t) ^ 2 * differential-d@(t))
S * gamma
((integral _ t _ 0) ^ (t _ 1))@(L * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * differential-d@(t))
(m / 2) * ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ (t _ 1))@((dot@(gamma) * t) ^ 2 * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
Suppose that

is satisfies the Euler-Lagrange equation for the Lagrangian

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) - (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(q)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) = 0

, so

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * m * dot@(gamma) * t = 0

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: m * ddot@(gamma) * t = 0

para.p:
so

The action of this path is
The dimensions of the right hand side are

which are indeed the dimensions that action ought to have. If instead of talking about action that is a function of paths we talk about action that is a function of the end point of a motion and the time at which the motion ends, taking the time and location at which the motion starts as fixed, then

Math.text: S * open-interval@(q, t) = (m / 2) * ((q - q _ 0) ^ 2 / (t - t _ 0))

para.p: for which

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q) = m * ((q - q _ 0) / (t - t _ 0))

para.p: and

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) = - (m / 2) * ((q - q _ 0) ^ 2 / (t - t _ 0) ^ 2)

para.p: These satisfy

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) + (1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 = 0

para.p: If we write

Math.text: H * open-interval@(q, p) = (p / m) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v)) * open-interval@(q, p / m) - L * open-interval@(q, p / m) = (p / m) cdot m cdot (p / m) - (m / 2) * (p / m) ^ 2 = p ^ 2 / (2 * m)

para.p: Then,

Math.text: (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t)) * open-interval@(q, t) + H * open-interval@(q, (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) * open-interval@(q, t)) = 0

para.p:
Suppose that
γ
is a path that satisfies the Euler-Lagrange equation for some Lagrangian
L
. If we perturb the path to start at the same position at time
t 0
but to end at
+ q
⁢ δ q
instead of at
q
, then the perturbed path is
↦ s
+
⁢ γ
( s )
⁢
(
⁢ δ γ
)
( s )
, where
=
⁢
(
⁢ δ γ
)
( 0 )
0
and
=
⁢
(
⁢ δ γ
)
( t )
⁢ δ q
. Then, first doing a Taylor approximation in which we drop all powers of
⁢ δ γ
or
⁢ δ
˙ γ
higher than the first and then using the Euler-Lagrange equation, and using Einstein summation notation,

Math.tex: \displaystyle S(\gamma+\delta\gamma)-S(\gamma)=\int_{t_{0}}^{t}L(\gamma+\delta% \gamma,\dot{\gamma}+\delta\dot{\gamma})-L(\gamma,\dot{\gamma})ds=\int_{t_{0}}^% {t}\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}(\gamma,\dot{\gamma})\delta\gamma_{i}+% \frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma,\dot{\gamma})\delta\dot{\gamma_{i}}ds% =\int_{t_{0}}^{t}\left(\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma,% \dot{\gamma})\right)\delta\gamma_{i}+\frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma,% \dot{\gamma})\delta\dot{\gamma_{i}}ds=\int_{t_{0}}^{t}\frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{% \partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma,\dot{\gamma})\delta\gamma_{i}\right)ds=% \frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma(t),\dot{\gamma}(t))(\delta\gamma_{i})% (t)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma(t_{0}),\dot{\gamma}(t_{0}))(% \delta\gamma_{i})(t_{0})=\frac{\partial L}{\partial v_{i}}(\gamma(t),\dot{% \gamma}(t))\delta q.
Math.text: S * (gamma + delta * gamma) - S * gamma = ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@(L * open-interval@(gamma + delta * gamma, dot@(gamma) + delta * dot@(gamma))) - L * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * d * s = ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(q _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i) + (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * dot@(gamma _ i) * d * s = ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((d / (d * t)) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i) + (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * dot@(gamma _ i) * d * s = ((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((d / (d * t)) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i * differential-d@(s)) = (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * delta * gamma _ i * t - (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t _ 0, dot@(gamma) * t _ 0) * delta * gamma _ i * t _ 0 = (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * delta * q
S * (gamma + delta * gamma) - S * gamma
((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@(L * open-interval@(gamma + delta * gamma, dot@(gamma) + delta * dot@(gamma))) - L * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * d * s

((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(q _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i) + (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * dot@(gamma _ i) * d * s

((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((d / (d * t)) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i) + (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * dot@(gamma _ i) * d * s
((integral _ t _ 0) ^ t)@((d / (d * t)) * (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma, dot@(gamma)) * delta * gamma _ i * differential-d@(s))

(partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * delta * gamma _ i * t - (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t _ 0, dot@(gamma) * t _ 0) * delta * gamma _ i * t _ 0
(partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) * delta * q

para.p:
We have not been precise about what we mean by perturbing a path, but what we have obtained suggests that if we think of
S
as a function of the endpoint of a path and the time at which the path ends rather than as a function of a path itself, we have

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q _ i) = (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * open-interval@(gamma * t, dot@(gamma) * t) = p _ i * t

para.p:
If on the other hand we fix the point
q
at which a path ends and change the time at which it arrives at this point from
t
to
+ t
⁢ δ t
, then, doing a Taylor expansion and dropping all powers of
⁢ δ t
higher than the first,

Math.text: gamma * (t + delta * t) - gamma * t = dot@(gamma) * t * delta * t

para.p:
But
=
⁢ γ
(
+ t
⁢ δ t
)
q
, so

Math.text: gamma * t = q - dot@(gamma) * t * delta * t

para.p: Then

Math.text: delta * S = L * delta * t - (partial-differential@(L) / partial-differential@(v _ i)) * v _ i * delta * t

para.p:
Defining
= H
-
⁢
∂ L
∂
v i
v i
L
, what we have done suggests that

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) = - H

para.p:
Then, using
=
∂ S
∂
q i
p i
, with which
=
⁢ H
( q , p )
⁢ H
( q ,
∂ S
∂ q
)
, and using
=
∂ S
∂ t
-
⁢ H
( q , p )
, we have

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) + H * open-interval@(q, partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) = 0

para.p: We call this equation the Hamilton-Jacobi equation.

To precisely sort out where the Hamilton-Jacobi equation comes from and what it means, the only place I can imagine that does an adequate job is Abraham and Marsden. 1 1 footnote 1 Abraham and Marsden, Foundations of Mechanics, second ed. Certainly there are other sources that present this more precisely than I have presented it, but it is almost universal to thoughtlessly confound the variables on which
H
or
S
depends with paths; that is, to write things like
∂ H
∂ q
and also to think of
q
not as a point but rather as a path which for each time goes through a particular point, in which case one has no certain way of knowing whether
=
⁢ d q
⁢ d t
0
, as is the case for the derivative of any fixed point, or to say that
q
is a path and that
⁢ d q
⁢ d t
is a tangent vector at the point
⁢ q
( t )
on the path. If one plainly states that what one has said is only suggestive of how symbols work together then one does not need to apologize for the absence of precision, but there is a foul area between suggestive symbol manipulation and actual precision in which one tricks oneself into believing that one has given a precise presentation, and this is the path followed by some presentations of the Hamilton-Jacobi equation.
Let
The Hamilton-Jacobi equation for this Hamiltonian is

Math.text: partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) + (1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 + (1 / 2) * m * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2 = 0

para.p:
We set
=
⁢ S
( q , t )
-
⁢
S 0
( q )
⁢ E t
; for this to make sense presumes that there is in fact a constant
E
and a function
S 0
so that
-
⁢ S
( q , t )
⁢
S 0
( q )
depends just on
t
. With this,
=
∂ S
∂ q
∂
S 0
∂ q
and
=
∂ S
∂ t
- E
, and so the Hamilton-Jacobi equation becomes

Math.text: (- E) + (1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S _ 0) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 + (1 / 2) * m * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2 = 0

para.p: or

Math.text: (1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S _ 0) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 + (1 / 2) * m * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2 = E

para.p:
Supposing that
S 0
is nonnegative we get

Math.text: (partial-differential@(S _ 0) / partial-differential@(q)) * q = square-root@(2 * m * E - m ^ 2 * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2)

para.p: a primitive of which is

Math.text: S _ 0 = integral@(square-root@(2 * m * E - m ^ 2 * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2) * differential-d@(q)) = (E / omega) * (inverse-sine@((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) + ((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) * square-root@(1 - ((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) ^ 2))
integral@(square-root@(2 * m * E - m ^ 2 * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2) * differential-d@(q))
(E / omega) * (inverse-sine@((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) + ((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) * square-root@(1 - ((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E)) ^ 2))

para.p: for which

Math.text: partial-differential@(S _ 0) / partial-differential@(E) = (1 / omega) * inverse-sine@((m * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * m * E))

para.p:
But
=
∂
S 0
∂ E
t
(using the expression involving
S
and
⁢ E t
), so
=
⁢ ω t
arcsin
⁢ m ω q
⁢ 2 m E
, hence

Math.text: sine@(omega * t) = (square-root@(m) * omega * q) / square-root@(2 * E)

para.p: and therefore

Math.text: q = square-root@((2 * E) / (m * omega ^ 2)) * sine@(omega * t)

para.p: As well,

Math.text: p = partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q) = partial-differential@(S _ 0) / partial-differential@(q) = square-root@(2 * m * E - m ^ 2 * omega ^ 2 * q ^ 2)

para.p:
and using the above expression for
q
this becomes

Math.text: p = square-root@(2 * m * E - m ^ 2 * omega ^ 2 * ((2 * E) / (m * omega ^ 2)) * (sine ^ 2)@(omega * t)) = square-root@(2 * m * E - 2 * m * E * (sine ^ 2)@(omega * t))

para.p:
We have thus written
q
and
p
as functions of
E
and
t
. Since for a particular trajectory the energy is fixed, on a particular trajectory the position and momentum have thus been expressed as functions of
t
.
Write

Math.text: i * Planck-constant-over-2-pi * (partial-differential@(psi) / partial-differential@(t)) = H * psi

para.p:
called the Schrödinger equation. If
=
⁢ H
( q , p )
+
p 2
⁢ 2 m
⁢ V
( q )
, and
= p
-
⁢ i ℏ ∇
, then
=
p 2
-
⁢
ℏ 2
Δ
and the Schrödinger equation is

Math.text: i * Planck-constant-over-2-pi * (partial-differential@(psi) / partial-differential@(t)) = (- (Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2 / (2 * m)) * Delta * psi) + V * q * psi

para.p:
Supposing that there is a solution
ψ
of the form
= ψ
e
⁢ i
S ℏ
, we get

Math.tex: \displaystyle i\hbar e^{i\frac{S}{\hbar}}\frac{i}{\hbar}\frac{\partial S}{% \partial t}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2m}\frac{\partial}{\partial q}\left(e^{i\frac{S}% {\hbar}}\frac{i}{\hbar}\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}\right)+V(q)e^{i\frac{S}{% \hbar}}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2m}\left(e^{i\frac{S}{\hbar}}\left(\frac{i}{\hbar}% \frac{\partial S}{\partial q}\right)^{2}+e^{i\frac{S}{\hbar}}\frac{i}{\hbar}% \frac{\partial^{2}S}{\partial q^{2}}\right)+V(q)e^{i\frac{S}{\hbar}}.
Math.text: i * Planck-constant-over-2-pi * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t)) = (- (Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(q)) * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q))) + V * q * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) = (- (Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2 / (2 * m)) * (e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * ((i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q))) ^ 2 + e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * ((partial-differential ^ 2)@(S) / partial-differential@(q ^ 2)))) + V * q * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi))
i * Planck-constant-over-2-pi * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t))

(- (Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(q)) * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q))) + V * q * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi))

(- (Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2 / (2 * m)) * (e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * ((i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q))) ^ 2 + e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi)) * (i / Planck-constant-over-2-pi) * ((partial-differential ^ 2)@(S) / partial-differential@(q ^ 2)))) + V * q * e ^ (i * (S / Planck-constant-over-2-pi))

para.p:
Diving both sides by
e
⁢ i
S ℏ
gives

Math.text: - partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) = ((1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 - ((i * Planck-constant-over-2-pi) / (2 * m)) * ((partial-differential ^ 2)@(S) / partial-differential@(q ^ 2))) + V * q

para.p:
Taking
→ ℏ 0
yields the equation

Math.tex: -\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}=\frac{1}{2m}\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}% \right)^{2}+V(q)=H\left(q,\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}\right),
Math.text: - partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(t) = (1 / (2 * m)) * (partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q)) ^ 2 + V * q = H * open-interval@(q, partial-differential@(S) / partial-differential@(q))

para.p: which is the Hamilton-Jacobi equation.

The above derivation of the Hamilton-Jacobi equation from the Schrödinger equation is suggestive symbol manipulation. Rather than stating that we assume
= ψ
e
⁢ i
S ℏ
, I could have written that we “make an Ansatz”; “ein Ansatz” means “an approach”, and is used to mean a guess which may work out. Of course, if there is some problem for which one knows there is a unique solution and we find an explicit solution starting from some unjustified assumption, then we don’t need to have justified the assumption because we can explicitly check that what we have found is a solution. But this is the only situation where there is precision to “making an Ansatz”. Otherwise, to talk about an Ansatz is a sophisticated sounding way of saying “we make an assumption”, and after making this assumption we have no guarantee that anything we end up with need make any sense. This does not mean that it is useless to make unjustified assumptions; but it is deceitful to smuggle Ansätze into the realm of proved things, and confuses those who later would rely on one’s work.
